revision.text:
{{About|Anti-Israeli protests|2011 Palestinian anti-government demonstrations|2011 Palestinian protests|2012 Palestinian anti-government demonstrations|2012 Palestinian protests}} {{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=April 2012}} {{globalize|date=April 2012}} {{disputed|date=April 2012}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2011 Israeli border demonstrations | partof = the [[Arab Spring]] | image = [[File:Burning the Israeli flag at embassy in Cairo.jpg|300px]] | caption = An Egyptian burning an [[Flag of Israel|Israeli flag]] during a [[Nakba Day]] protest at the Israeli embassy in [[Cairo]]. | place = [[Borders of Israel]]
{{bulleted list |{{Flagu|Egypt}} |{{Flagu|Jordan}} |{{Flagu|Lebanon}} |{{flagu|Palestinian National Authority}} |{{flagu|Syria}}}} | date = {{start date|df=yes|2011|05|15}} and {{end date|df=yes|2011|06|05}} | status = Ended | goals = | howmany1 = 30,000+ protesters | causes = Observance of [[Nakba Day]] | methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]] | injuries = 380–730+ | fatalities = 12–40{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/201167143318466482.html|title=UN's Pillay condemns Israeli 'Naksa' killings|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=12 June 2011|date=8 June 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110606-syria-says-23-dead-israel-opens-fire-golan# |title=Syria says 23 dead as Israel opens fire on Golan |author=[[Agence France Presse]] |publisher=[[France 24]] |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=12 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609033742/http://www.france24.com/en/20110606-syria-says-23-dead-israel-opens-fire-golan |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df=dmy }} | arrests = | concessions = }} The '''2011 Israeli border demonstrations''' started on 15 May 2011, to commemorate what the [[Palestinians]] observe as [[Nakba Day]]. Various groups of people attempted to approach or breach [[Israel's borders]] from the [[Palestinian Authority|Palestinian-controlled territory]], [[Lebanon]], [[Syria]], [[Egypt]] and [[Jordan]]. At least a dozen people were killed when protesters attempted to cross the border from Syria.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13373006|title=Israeli forces open fire at Palestinian protesters|publisher=BBC News |date=16 May 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520024042/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13373006| archivedate= 20 May 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 5 June 2011, there were further protests on the border with Syria and, according to Syrian authorities, 23 protesters were killed and 350 wounded by live fire from Israeli forces, though Israeli sources suggested these figures were exaggerated. Israeli army spokesman Yoav Mordechai accused Syria of creating "a provocation" at the border to distract attention from the Syrian government's crackdown on the [[Civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian uprising]].{{cite news |author1=Samuel Sockol |author2=Joel Greenberg |author3=Sufian Taha |date=5 June 2011 |title=Israeli troops, Palestinians clash at Golan Heights frontier |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/palestinian-protesters-attempt-to-cross-at-golan-heights-israeli-troops-open-fire/2011/06/05/AG7nUWJH_story.html}} == 15 May events== {{Main article|2011 Nakba Day#Border demonstrations}} Inspired by the [[Arab Spring|uprisings and revolutions taking place in the Arab world]], Palestinians used Facebook to call for mass protests throughout the region on 15 May 2011 Nakba Day.{{cite news |author=Karin Laub |agency=Associated Press |date=May 17, 2011 |newspaper=[[Daily Herald (Utah)|Daily Herald]] |location=Provo, Utah |url=http://www.heraldextra.com/news/world/article_10865d67-e7a6-57cf-af4b-dd705e5a19b5.html |title=Palestinians test tactic of unarmed mass marches}} {{cite news |author= Sami Moubayed |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/ME18Ak03.html |title=Persistence will pay off for Palestinians |publisher=Asia Times |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011| archiveurl= https://archive.is/20110622094133/http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/ME18Ak03.html| archivedate= 22 June 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news |url=http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=33601 |title=Army fires on Cairo's Nakba rally |publisher=Bikyamasr.com |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721165108/http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=33601 |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4069686,00.html |title=Syrian infiltrator recounts journey to TA |publisher=Ynetnews |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=6 June 2011}} A page calling for a "Third Palestinian Intifada" to begin on 15 May was started on 9 March 2011, garnered more than 350,000 "likes" before being taken down by Facebook managers at the end of March after complaints from the Israeli government as well as a counter group which repeatedly requested Facebook to block the page on the grounds that it incited violence.{{cite news |url=http://www.thirdage.com/news/israeli-troops-clash-with-palestinian-protesters_05-15-2011?page=2 |title=Israeli Troops Clash with Palestinian Protesters |publisher=Thirdage.com |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611040127/http://www.thirdage.com/news/israeli-troops-clash-with-palestinian-protesters_05-15-2011?page=2 |archivedate=11 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-29/world/palestinian.facebook_1_facebook-page-social-media-website-incites-violence?_s=PM:WORLD |title=Facebook page supporting Palestinian intifada pulled down |publisher=CNN |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110624035859/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-29/world/palestinian.facebook_1_facebook-page-social-media-website-incites-violence?_s=PM%3AWORLD |archivedate=24 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The page called for mass marches to Israel and Palestinian Authority from Egypt, Lebanon, Syria and Jordan to commemorate the Nakba and demand the [[Palestinian right of return|right of return]] for all Palestinian refugees.{{cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11737/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptians-call-for-a-march-to-Palestine-on-Nakba-d.aspx |title=Egyptians to mark Nakba with a march to Palestine |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |accessdate=6 June 2011}} ===Egypt=== Organizers in Egypt had been preparing for weeks to implement the calls made on Facebook for a mass march to the border. On Saturday 14 May, thousands were planning to make their way toward the [[Rafah crossing]] with [[Gaza City|Gaza]] in convoys set to depart from Cairo, Alexandria, Suez, Damietta, North Sinai, Gharbiya, Beni Suef, Assiut, Qena and Sohag. However, an order from the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] to tourism companies not to send buses to the convoy organizers left them without sufficient transportation and the few buses they did manage to procure were stopped by the [[Egyptian army|army]]. The blockage of access by [[Military of Egypt|Egyptian forces]] to the [[Sinai Peninsula]], meant that only about 80 activists managed to reach the border with Rafah.[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=387910 Egyptians rally at Rafah for Palestinian rights]. [[Ma'an News Agency]] . 15 May 2011. ===Jordan=== In Jordan, 200 Palestinian students attempted to march towards the Israeli border, but were restrained by Jordanian security forces resulting in the injury of six people.Muir, Jim. [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13406869 Palestinian protests: Arab spring or foreign manipulation?]. [[BBC News]]. 15 May 2011. They were part of a larger group of 500 who were stopped at the [[Allenby Bridge]]. Jordanian authorities said a total of 25 people were injured, including 11 police officers. The political arm of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] in Jordan, the [[Islamic Action Front]], condemned police actions which they described as "shocking" stating: "We condemn the attack, which is part of government policies to impose its will on the people, and we demand an end to such policies that have harmed Jordan's image."[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=388312 Jordan police say 25 hurt in Nakba clashes]. [[Ma'an News Agency]]. 16 May 2011. ===Lebanon=== Activists had organized an event on a mountaintop in the village of [[Maroun al-Ras]] that overlooks the border with Israel. Some 30,000 people, including Palestinian refugees from various [[Palestinian refugee camp]]s across Lebanon attended.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2011/May-17/Palestinian-refugee-camps-bury-Nakba-martyrs.ashx |title=Palestinian refugee camps bury Nakba martyrs |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]] |location=Lebanon |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011}} After walking up the mountain to the protest site, many decided to descend the opposite side, and continued on towards the border. [[Lebanese Armed Forces|Lebanese Army]] soldiers fired into the air in a failed effort to deter them.{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/newsbook/2011/05/israel|title=Israel: Unrest on the borders|work=The Economist|date=15 May 2011|accessdate=16 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519061435/https://www.economist.com/blogs/newsbook/2011/05/israel| archivedate= 19 May 2011 | deadurl= no}} Crossing through a minefield that was laid by Israel during the [[2006 Lebanon War]], they reached the border fence, and threw stones over it, chanting for their right of return. The Lebanese army intervened and began firing M16 assault rifles and tear gas, which sent protesters fleeing back up the mountain.{{cite news |title=In Pictures: Nakba day violence on the Israel-Lebanon border|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/photo_galleries/middleeast/2011516141741145621.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English}} Eleven participants were killed and 100 injured by gunfire before the protesters retreated.{{cite news |author=Gil Stern Shefler |date=2 August 2011 |title=Prosor slams Lebanon violations in letter to Ban |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |url=https://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Prosor-slams-Lebanon-violations-in-letter-to-Ban}} There were conflicting reports of who shot them. Media reported that the protesters were shot by the IDF. The IDF said most of those killed were likely shot by the [[Lebanese Armed Forces]] (LAF) and that they had a video that established this, but would not release it on the grounds that it might cause embarrassment to the Lebanese Army.{{cite news |last=Pinkas |first=Alon |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?id=220904 |title=IDF withholds video of Lebanese firing on protesters |work=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=6 June 2011}} ===Gaza Strip=== Between 500 and 600 Palestinians marched towards the [[Erez Crossing]], a border crossing between Israel and the Gaza Strip on 15 May. Palestinian medical officials said that IDF forces fired on the group intermittently over the course of a couple of hours with tanks, machine guns, gas canisters and sound bombs, killing one demonstrator and wounding more than 80.{{cite web |date=16 May 2011 |title=Israeli military's killing of Nakba protesters must be investigated |publisher=Amnesty International |format=PDF}}{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1639368.php/Israel-Syria-Lebanon-borders-calm-after-Palestinian-Nakba-protest |title=Israel-Syria-Lebanon borders calm after Palestinian Nakba protest |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=14 May 1948 |accessdate=18 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519234719/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1639368.php/Israel-Syria-Lebanon-borders-calm-after-Palestinian-Nakba-protest |archive-date=19 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=393931|title=Israel quashes West Bank protests|date=2011-06-05|access-date=2016-02-29|publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]]}} ===Palestinian Authority=== In the West Bank, Palestinians from a burgeoning new youth movement convened seminars on strategies for non-violent resistance to prepare for a 15 May march on the [[Qalandia]] checkpoint separating [[Ramallah]] from [[Jerusalem]], and several of them were arrested by [[Palestinian Authority]] police in the month before the protest date. On 15 May, more than 1,000 protestors marched through the Qalandia refugee camp until they reached within 100 metres of the checkpoint separating [[Ramallah]] from [[Jerusalem]] where Israeli forces used tear gas to disperse most of them.{{cite news |author=Kieron Monks |date=16 May 2011 |title=Green shoots emerge at Qalandia checkpoint |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/05/201151611522564602.html}}{{cite news |author=Jon Donnison |date=16 May 2011 |title=Palestinians emboldened by Arab Spring |publisher=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13417788}} Around 100 Palestinian protesters engaged in a standoff with Israeli forces over the next seven hours, throwing stones, as Israeli troops fired tear gas and rubber bullets. More than 80 protestors, including three paramedics, sustained injuries and twenty were hospitalized; a doctor at the hospital said the last time he saw so many casualties in one day was during the [[Second Intifada]]. ===Syria=== In Syria, the events were organized by phone and internet by Palestinian refugees, most of them university students independent of any political faction, in response to the call for a "Third Palestinian Intifada" on Facebook.{{cite news |last=Haddad |first=Rim |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hORDwISozjMd3J4mnoJRPRbpY9vA?docId=CNG.24720c3e4e4b36a7a28281c90f818eda.281 |title=Shot Palestinian youth proud of Golan protest |publisher=Google |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140131025725/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hORDwISozjMd3J4mnoJRPRbpY9vA?docId=CNG.24720c3e4e4b36a7a28281c90f818eda.281 |archive-date=31 January 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/may/19/nakba-day-palestinian-summer |title=Nakba day: we waited 63 years for this |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=6 June 2011 |first=Karma |last=Nabulsi |date=19 May 2011}} Demonstrators gathered near the Israeli-Syrian [[Purple Line (ceasefire line)|ceasefire line]] waving [[Palestinian flag]]s, and then marched toward and breached the fence, entering the Israeli-controlled [[Golan Heights]].{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/opinion/israel-was-infiltrated-but-no-real-borders-were-crossed-1.362215|title=Israel was infiltrated, but no real borders were crossed|author=Gideon Biger|date=17 May 2011|newspaper=Haaretz|accessdate=18 May 2011}} The first wave of demonstrators to move toward the fence were stopped by Syrian police who were later overtaken when a second group arrived. The sole Israeli patrol present was similarly overwhelmed and opened fire on the demonstrators.{{cite web|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=46168 |title='They crossed minefields,' Golan residents marvel |publisher=Middle East Online |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011}} Four demonstrators were killed and dozens injured.[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/05/2011515649440342.html Palestinians killed in 'Nakba' clashes]. [[Al-Jazeera English]]. 15 May 2011. The Israeli military stated that it only fired warning shots when about 1,000 demonstrators approached the fence, and some 300 children among them, rushed toward the fence.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13373006 Israeli forces open fire at Palestinian protesters]. [[BBC News]]. 15 May 2011. More than a hundred managed to bypass the fence and enter the Arab [[Druze]] town of [[Majdal Shams]].{{cite news |author=Hanan Greenberg |date=15 May 2011 |publisher=Ynetnews |url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4069033,00.html |title=IDF says handled border breach well}}{{cite web|last=Pfeffer |first=Anshel |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/idf-unprepared-for-syria-border-breach-despite-intelligence-tips-1.362173 |title=IDF unprepared for Syria border breach, despite intelligence tips |work=Haaretz |date=27 April 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011}} About a dozen members of Israel's security forces were injured in clashes in Majdal Shams. Two demonstrators were arrested and detained, but were returned to Syria. == 5 June events == {{See also|Naksa Day}} ===Gaza Strip=== In the northern Gaza Strip, dozens of demonstrators tried to march towards the Erez border crossing with Israel. Hamas police had erected checkpoints to stop protesters from reaching Israel's border and clashed with protestors, arresting around a dozen who had left a rally organized in the northern town of [[Beit Hanun]]. ===Palestinian Authority=== At the Qalandia checkpoint in the West Bank, around 300 demonstrated in a protest that began with about 10 people forming a human chain in front of Israeli soldiers who responded with tear gas, sound bombs and rubber bullets. After they sat on the ground refusing to leave, they were forcefully removed by soldiers in riot gear and youth at the back of the crowd began throwing stones. Over the course of several hours, 120 were injured, mostly by tear gas, but also by rubber bullets, sound bombs, and a new stink spray being used for crowd control purposes. Dozens of protesters from the northern West Bank village of [[Deir al-Hatab]] also tried to march to the nearby [[Elon Moreh]] settlement. ===Lebanon=== Palestinian organizers in Lebanon planned for a march along the Lebanese-Israeli border for 5 June, but following a decision by the Lebanese Army to ban all protests along the border, the "Palestinian preparatory committee of the return march" canceled the protest on 3 June.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2011/Jun-07/Strikes-continue-in-wake-of-Golan-Naksa-killings |title=News :: Politics :: Strikes continue in wake of Golan Naksa killings |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]] |location=Lebanon |accessdate=10 June 2011}} Palestinian refugees in Lebanon held strikes instead. Groups independent of the Return to Palestine March Committee still attempted to reach the border, and the Lebanese army stopped a group of 20 youths in the border town of [[Kfar Kila]].{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/06/201168131013184315.html|title=Palestinian activism energised by Arab Spring|publisher=Al Jazeera English|author=Yasmine Ryan|accessdate=12 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110611113903/http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/06/201168131013184315.html| archivedate= 11 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} ===Syria=== {{further|Civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War}} [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - IDF Soldiers Near Israel-Syria Border Following "Naksa Day" Riots.jpg|thumb|left|upright|IDF photo:"IDF Soldiers Near Israel-Syria Border Following "[[Naksa Day|Naksa Day" Riots]]"]] On 5 June 2011 Palestinian and Syrian protesters moved towards the Golan Heights line of control near [[Quneitra]] and [[Majdal Shams]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2082080.ece|title=Israeli army on alert for second day along border with Syria|work=The Hindu |location=India|date=6 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}} According to Syrian officials, 23 people were killed and 350 people were injured by Israeli snipers as they attempted over the course of several hours to breach the barbed-wire border.{{cite news |date=6 June 2011 |url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Protests-continue-on-the-border-at-Golan,-23-killed-yesterday-by-Israeli-fire-21750.html |title=Protests continue on the border at Golan, 23 killed yesterday by Israeli fire |publisher=AsiaNews}} Among the dead was also reportedly an unarmed 12-year-old boy.[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/israeli-troops-kill-14-including-12yearold-boy-as-protesters-bid-for-border-16008341.html "Israeli troops kill 14, including 12-year-old boy, as protesters bid for border"], Catrina Stewart. Belfast Telegraph. 6 June 2011. Accessed 6 June 2011 According to Israeli officials, they counted 10 dead, none of whom were killed by Israeli fire. ''The New York Times'' said that, either way, this clash produced the greatest loss of life in the Golan since the [[Yom Kippur War]] in 1973.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/06/world/middleeast/06mideast.html|title=Israeli Soldiers Shoot at Protesters on Syrian Border|work=The New York Times|date=5 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011|first=Isabel|last=Kershner| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110611055352/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/06/world/middleeast/06mideast.html| archivedate=11 June 2011| deadurl= no}} Palestinians from the suburbs of [[Damascus]] were reportedly bused into the area and massed the border without interference from Syrian troops.{{cite news |title=IDF rebuffs 'Naksa' rioters trying to cross Syrian border |author=Yaakov Lappin and Herb Keinon |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?id=223768 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011}} The IDF described this as a provocation by President Bashar Assad, that was designed to distract world attention away from the ongoing "slaughter of protesters" in Syria by Assad's troops, referring to the [[civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian uprising]]. Israeli soldiers shouted warnings in Arabic via loudspeakers asking the Palestinians to refrain from trying to cross the frontier, adding that those who did so would endanger their lives. Israeli forces were under orders to prevent the protesters from crossing the line of control. Although no protesters managed to cross the border, the protesters thought the day was a success, as they believed that there would be outrage against Israeli troops for firing on unarmed protesters. In response the [[US State Department]] said that it was "troubled" by the loss of life,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13660311|title=Golan: Israel troops fire on pro-Palestinian protesters|publisher=BBC |date=5 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110606112256/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13660311| archivedate= 6 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} but noted that Israel has the right to defend its sovereign borders.{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?ID=223757&R=R1|title=US on Naksa clashes: Israel has right to defend itself|publisher=Jerusalem Post|date=6 June 2011|accessdate=6 June 2011}} In the aftermath, thousands began a sit-in near Golan,[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2011/Jun-06/Lebanons-Arabic-press-digest---June-6-2011.ashx "Press Digest"], [[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]] (Lebanon). 6 June 2011. Accessed 6 June 2011 resulting in the Syrian government creating a security buffer zone for humanitarian purposes.[http://www.bostonherald.com/news/international/middle_east/view/20110606syria_blocks_new_border_protest_toll_rises_to_23/srvc=home&position=recent "Syria blocks new protest at Israeli border"], Boston Herald. 6 June 2011. Accessed 6 June 2011 Paramedics on the Syrian side of the border asked that the IDF grant them cease-fires to clear the wounded. The army agreed to the request, but then saw activists exploiting the quiet to try to cut the border fence, bringing the truce to an end. One of those killed, Ezzat Maswadi, was a Palestinian born in [[Jerusalem]] in 1977, who grew up in [[al-Eizariya]]. His father, who lives in al-Eizariya, could not procure a permit to travel to Damascus to attend his funeral.{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110610-syria-refugees-dream-return-ends-tragedy|title=Syria refugee's dream of return ends in tragedy|agency=Agence France Presse|publisher=France 24|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=12 June 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614202807/http://www.france24.com/en/20110610-syria-refugees-dream-return-ends-tragedy|archive-date=14 June 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The United States lobby group the [[Syrian Reform Party]] issued a statement accusing the Syrian regime of hiring Syrian protesters to storm the border to deflect attention from its own crackdown against the [[2011 Syrian uprising]], further claiming that protesters were paid about 1,000 dollars for protesting, with 10,000 being offered to their family if the protester was killed.{{cite web|url=http://reformsyria.org/syrian-opposition/rps-statement-concerning-the-assad-stompers-of-the-golan-heights |title=RPS Statement Concerning the Assad Stompers of the Golan Heights – Syrian Opposition – Reform Party of Syria |publisher=Reform Syria |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Syrian State TV reported six hours live from the incident, and it is claimed that it did not report on Syrian crackdowns during that time.{{cite web|url=http://www.hagalil.com/archiv/2011/06/07/syrien-8/ |title=Bürgerkrieg in Syrien |publisher=haGalil |accessdate=10 June 2011}} Clashes broke out at a funeral for the dead in the [[Palestinian refugee camp]] of [[Yarmouk, Damascus|Yarmouk]] in [[Damascus]] on 6 June. Allegedly angered by the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine – General Command|PFLP-GC]]'s refusal to take part in the protests, thousands of mourners attacked and burnt-down its headquarters in Yarmouk. PFLP-GC members opened-fire on the crowd, killing 14 Palestinians and wounding 43.[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/2011673373245769.html 'Naksa' deaths spark Palestinian violence] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607113742/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/2011673373245769.html |date=7 June 2011 }}[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=394412 "Report: 14 Palestinians killed in Syria camp"]. [[Ma'an News Agency]], 8 June 2011. Retrieved 26 February 2013.[http://electronicintifada.net/blogs/ali-abunimah/mass-shooting-reported-yarmouk-palestinian-refugee-camp-syria-video "Mass shooting reported in Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Syria – video"]. [[The Electronic Intifada]], 6 June 2011. Retrieved 26 February 2013.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/08/world/middleeast/08damascus.html?_r=1&ref=global-home | work=The New York Times | first=Isabel | last=Kershner | title=Fighters Shoot Protesters at a Palestinian Camp in Syria | date=7 June 2011}} ==See also== {{portal|Syrian Civil War}} *[[Land Day]] *[[2018 Gaza border protests]] ==References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Arab Spring}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Israeli Border Demonstrations, 2011}} [[Category:Protests in the Palestinian territories]] [[Category:2011 in Israel|Border Demonstrations]] [[Category:2011 in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 in Jordan]] [[Category:2011 in Lebanon]] [[Category:2011 in the Palestinian territories]] [[Category:2011 in the Gaza Strip]] [[Category:2011 in Syria]] [[Category:Arab Spring by country|Israel]] [[Category:May 2011 events]] [[Category:June 2011 events]] [[Category:Borders of Israel]

{{Infobox event | title = 2018 Kuwait–Philippine diplomatic crisis | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = | date = January – May 2018 | type = [[Diplomatic crisis]] | theme = [[Labor relations]] | cause = Discovery of the murder of a Joanna Demafelis, a Filipino migrant worker | motive = Improvement of working conditions for Filipino migrant workers | participants = Governments of Kuwait and the Philippines | outcome = ;Crisis *[[List of deployment ban on Overseas Filipino Workers|Total labor deployment ban]] for Filipino migrant workers to Kuwait
{{small|(informally since January 2018; February 2018 to May 2018)}} *Expulsion of Philippine Ambassador to Kuwait *Recall of Kuwait envoy in Manila ;Resolution *Conviction for Demafelis' kilers *Agreement on labor relations signed *Memorandum on agreement on labor relations signed | arrests = Nader Essam Assaf and his wife (February 2018) | verdict = | convictions = [[Murder]] (April 2018) | sentence = [[Death-penalty|Death]] by [[hanging]] | litigation = | url = | blank_label = | website = | notes = }} A diplomatic crisis began between the countries of Kuwait and the Philippines in early 2018 over concerns of the latter over the situation of Filipino migrant workers in the gulf country. The diplomatic row was a result of the discovery of the corpse of Joanna Demafelis, a Filipino domestic worker working in Kuwait which has been inside an abandoned warehouse since November 2016. In response to the discovery, President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] ordered the suspension of deployment of Filipino migrant workers to Kuwait and organized a voluntary repatriation program for Filipinos already working in Kuwait. The move was criticized by the Kuwaiti government but both the Philippines and Kuwait went on to cooperate regarding the Demafelis murder case leading to the conviction of Demafelis' killers ''[[in absentia]]'' as well as improve the working conditions of Filipino migrant workers in Kuwait in general. However relations were further strained in late-April after a video emerged showing Philippine embassy officials purportedly rescuing Filipino maids from allegedly abusive employers. Kuwait called the operations as a violation of its sovereignty, expelled the Philippine Ambassador to Kuwait and recalled its own envoy in [[Manila]]. ==Background== A diplomatic crisis between Kuwait and the Philippines began when the killing of Joanna Demafelis, a Filipino domestic worker working in Kuwait, came to public attention in 2018. The Philippine [[Department of Labor and Employment (Philippines)|Department of Labor and Employment]] directed its staff to stop processing deployment certificates to Filipinos seeking to work on Kuwait on January 19, 2018 following a series of death of Filipino domestic workers mentioned by President Rodrigo Duterte in a speech the day before.{{cite news|title=DOLE bans OFW deployment to Kuwait|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/01/19/18/dole-bans-ofw-deployment-to-kuwait|accessdate=25 April 2018|work=ABS-CBN News|date=19 January 2018}} Duterte has requested for a total ban of Filipino worker deployment to Kuwait.{{cite news|last1=Bacungan|first1=VJ|title=DOLE suspends OFW deployment to Kuwait|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2018/01/20/DOLE-suspend-OFW-kuwait.html|accessdate=26 April 2018|work=CNN Philippines|date=20 January 2018}} The case of Demafelis was the particular incident that resulted to the ban. Demafelis had been killed two years earlier and her death only came to public attention when her corpse was found inside a freezer in a warehouse abandoned since November 2016. It was on February 12, 2018, that DOLE officially enforced a deployment ban of Filipino migrant workers in Kuwait.{{cite news|last1=Patinio|first1=Ferdinand|title=DOLE orders total deployment ban of OFWs to Kuwait|url=http://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1024931|accessdate=26 April 2018|agency=Philippine News Agency|date=12 February 2018}} It was clarified that seafarers boarding from Kuwait, rehired workers who would be returning to the gulf country, and tourists are exempted from the ban.{{cite news|title=Gov't issues exemptions to ban on Kuwait-bound workers|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2018/02/14/Kuwait-OFW-deployment-ban.html|accessdate=14 February 2018|work=CNN Philippines|date=14 February 2018}} In addition to the deployment ban, the Philippine government has offered Filipino workers already in Kuwait to be voluntarily [[repatriated]].{{cite news|title=Kuwait invites Philippine president to visit amid workers row|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-kuwait-labour/kuwait-invites-philippine-president-to-visit-amid-workers-row-idUSKCN1G31GS|accessdate=26 April 2018|agency=Reuters|date=19 February 2018}} There are around 250,000 Filipinos working in Kuwait, 65 percent of which are domestic helpers, according to the Philippine embassy in 2018.{{cite news|title=Kuwait calms Philippines after dead worker found in freezer|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2018/02/14/kuwait-calms-philippines-after-dead-worker-found-freezer-588911|accessdate=14 February 2018|work=Sun Star Manila|date=14 February 2018}} ==Developments== ===Kuwaiti government response=== The Kuwaiti government has criticized the migrant worker ban imposed by the Philippines in gulf country and has stated that all cases of alleged abuse against Filipino migrant workers are being handled by its laws. The [[National Assembly of Kuwait]] has discussed the situation of the Filipino migrant workers in the country.{{cite news|last1=Izzak|first1=B|title=Assembly set to debate report on Filipino workers|url=http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/assembly-set-debate-report-filipino-workers/|accessdate=24 April 2018|work=Kuwait Times}} On April 3, 2018, the Kuwait government announced that it aims to recruit more Ethiopians as domestic workers to compensate for deficit in the labor force caused by its diplomatic row with the Philippines.{{cite news|title=Kuwait to recruit Ethiopians amid Philippines labor crisis|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/overseas/04/03/18/kuwait-to-recruit-ethiopians-amid-philippines-labor-crisis|accessdate=26 April 2018|work=ABS-CBN News|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=3 April 2018}} ===Repatriation of Filipino workers=== [[File:Kuwait OFWs repatriation Bahrain a.jpg|thumb|The Philippine Ambassador to Bahrain speaking with Filipino workers from Kuwait who are transiting through the Bahrain International Airport.]] By the end of March 2018, 4,000 Filipino workers has been voluntarily repatriated from Kuwait and the Philippine government is negotiating with Kuwait for the repatriation of 6,000 more workers{{cite news|title=Kuwait court condemns couple to death for Filipina in freezer murder|url=http://www.nst.com.my/world/2018/04/351845/kuwait-court-condemns-couple-death-filipina-freezer-murder|accessdate=23 June 2018|work=New Straits Times|agency=Agence France Presse|date=1 April 2018}} ===Demafelis murder case=== Lebanese man Nader Essam Assaf, and his Syrian wife were accused for the killing of Demafelis. With the help of [[Interpol]] the two were detained in the Syrian capital of [[Damascus]] in February 2018. The Syrian government handed custody of Assaf to Lebanon while Assaf's wife remained in Syria. On April 1, 2018, a Kuwaiti court convicted the couple of murder and [[death penalty|sentenced them to death]] [[hanging|by hanging]]. They were tried ''[[In absentia|in absentia]]''. ===April 21 Philippine embassy operation=== Relations between the two countries became more strained when a video emerged depicting operations of Philippine embassy officials purportedly rescuing Filipino maids from alleged abusive employers. The operation conducted on April 21, 2018 was seen by Kuwait as a "flagrant" violation of its [[sovereignty]]. Filipino diplomats in the Philippines insist that the operations were not clandestine.{{cite news|title=Kuwait expels Filipino envoy, recalls own ambassador|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/04/kuwait-expels-filipino-envoy-recalls-ambassador-180425160337686.html|accessdate=26 April 2018|work=Al Jazeera|date=25 April 2018}} Two embassy staff members were alleged to have encourage Filipino migrant workers to leave their employers.{{cite news|last1=Roxas|first1=Patricia Ann|title=Legarda fears PH-Kuwait row may affect bilateral relations|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/166188/legarda-fears-ph-kuwait-row-may-affect-bilateral-relations|accessdate=26 April 2018|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=26 April 2018}} [[File:Duterte meets Kuwait envoy.jpg|300px|thumb|President Duterte and Kuwaiti Ambassador to the Philippines Musaed Saleh Ahmad Althwaikh exchange pleasantries following their meeting at the [[ Malacañang of the South|Presidential Guest House]] in [[Davao City]] on April 23, 2018.]] The Philippine government on April 24 apologized for the incident saying it acknowledges Kuwait has its own laws while maintaining that the welfare of Filipino migrant workers are also within its interest. The following day, Kuwait declared Philippine Ambassador Renato Villa ''[[persona non grata]]'' demanding Villa to leave the gulf country within the week, and recalled its envoy in Manila for consultations. The Philippines called the move "deeply disturbing" and said that Kuwait "reneged" on an earlier agreement to cooperate. Kuwait arrested four drivers and three diplomats involved in the operation and pressed charges against them.{{cite news|last1=Mercado|first1=Ver|title=Malacañang: 4 Filipino drivers released after meeting between PH, Kuwait officials|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2018/05/09/kuwait-philippines-harry-roque-drivers-released.html|accessdate=13 May 2018|work=CNN Philippines|date=10 May 2018}} Following a meeting between officials of the two countries, the four drivers involved were released and the charges against them were dropped. ==Agreement== ===Negotiations=== Authorities from both countries have been engaged in talks to defuse diplomatic tensions. On February 14, 2018, the governments of Kuwait and the Philippines announced they come to consensus to sign an agreement on working conditions regulations. Philippine president [[Rodrigo Duterte]] has also been invited to make a state visit to Kuwait.{{cite news|title=Kuwait invites Philippine president to visit amid workers row|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-kuwait-labour/kuwait-invites-philippine-president-to-visit-amid-workers-row-idUSKCN1G31GS|accessdate=26 April 2018|agency=Reuters|date=19 February 2018}} Duterte, on March 6, laid two conditions for the labor deployment ban on Kuwait to be lifted; the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding on labor policies between Kuwait and the Philippines, and that "justice be served" in regards to the death of Joanna Demafelis.{{cite news|title=Duterte sets 2 conditions for lifting of deployment ban to Kuwait|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/duterte-sets-2-conditions-lifting-deployment-ban-kuwait/384423/|accessdate=26 April 2018|work=The Manila Times|date=6 March 2018}} On March 16, a draft agreement was accomplished by officials from the two countries and was expected to be signed in Kuwait in two weeks.{{cite news|title=Philippines fails to lift total ban on deployment of Filipino workers to Kuwait|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/philippines-fails-to-lift-total-ban-on-deployment-of-filipino-workers-to-kuwait/|accessdate=25 April 2018|work=Arab Times|date=20 March 2018}} Despite Kuwait's action on the Philippine Ambassador and its own envoy in Manila, Philippine Foreign Secretary [[Alan Peter Cayetano]] stated on April 25, that the agreement is now planned to be signed in the Philippines and the Kuwait government has followed-up regarding the agreement. Cayetano also encouraged Duterte to accept Kuwait's invitation to make a state visit to the Middle Eastern country.{{cite news|title=OFW welfare deal with Kuwait to be signed in PH|url=https://news.mb.com.ph/2018/04/25/ofw-welfare-deal-with-kuwait-to-be-signed-in-ph/|accessdate=26 April 2018|work=Manila Bulletin|date=26 April 2018}} However, President Rodrigo Duterte shortly declared that the labor deployment ban as "permanent".{{cite news|title=Philippines' Duterte calls Kuwait work ban 'permanent'|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/article/533792/World/Mena/Philippines-Duterte-calls-Kuwait-work-ban-permanent|accessdate=29 April 2018|work=Saudi Gazette|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=29 April 2018}} Duterte also said that the signing of the labor agreement with Kuwait will not push through and that he will not make a visit to the gulf country.{{cite news|last1=Montano|first1=Efren|title=No more labor deal with Kuwait|url=http://www.journal.com.ph/news/top-stories/no-more-labor-deal-with-kuwait|accessdate=29 April 2018|work=Journal Online|date=29 April 2018}} [[Harry Roque]], the Philippine presidential spokesperson later contradicted Duterte's statement saying that the ban is not "permanent" and may still be lifted.{{cite news|last1=Placido|first1=Dharel|title=Kuwait deployment ban not permanent, says Palace|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/overseas/04/30/18/kuwait-deployment-ban-not-permanent-says-palace|accessdate=30 April 2018|work=ABS-CBN|date=30 April 2018}} ===Signing=== [[File:Kuwait Philippines Agreement on the Employment of Domestic Workers signing 2.jpg|300px|thumb|Signing of the "Agreement on the Employment of Domestic Workers" between Kuwait in the Philippines which was led by Kuwaiti Foreign Minister [[Sabah Al-Khalid Al-Sabah]] and Philippine Foreign Affairs Secretary [[Alan Peter Cayetano]].]] The memorandum of agreement (MoU) entitled "Agreement on the Employment of Domestic Workers" between the Philippines and Kuwait"{{cite news|last1=Toumi|first1=Habib|title=Kuwait, Philippines sign deal to regulate domestic labour|url=https://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/kuwait-philippines-sign-deal-to-regulate-domestic-labour-1.2219791|accessdate=12 May 2018|work=Gulf News|agency=Gulf News Bureau|date=11 May 2018}} was signed by representatives of Kuwait and the Philippines was signed on May 11, 2018.{{cite news|title=Philippines signs agreement with Kuwait to protect workers|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/philippines-signs-agreement-kuwait-protect-workers-1965364693|accessdate=12 May 2018|work=Middle East Eye|date=11 May 2018}} The two countries had a consensus on labor matters which covered all migrant domestic workers in Kuwait regardless of their nationality{{cite news|last1=Terrazola|first1=Vanne Elaine|title=PH should make sure that Kuwait will uphold what was agreed upon in worker rights deal|url=https://news.mb.com.ph/2018/05/12/ph-should-make-sure-that-kuwait-will-uphold-what-was-agreed-upon-in-worker-rights-deal/|accessdate=13 May 2018|work=Manila Bulletin|date=12 May 2018}} Under the deal, certain rights of migrant workers were recognized: They can't have their passports and other travel documents kept by their employers; right to use their mobile phones. Workers are now also entitled to be provided food, housing, clothing, and health insurance by their employers{{cite news|title=Philippines and Kuwait sign agreement on workers' rights|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-44088011|accessdate=13 May 2018|work=BBC|date=11 May 2018}} and at least a day off from work.{{cite news|last1=Al-Khoweylidi|first1=Mirza|title=Kuwait, Philippines Normalize Relations|url=https://aawsat.com/english/home/article/1265876/kuwait-philippines-normalize-relations|accessdate=13 May 2018|work=Asharq Al-aswat|date=12 May 2018}} Filipino workers can't be a transferred to another employer without the consent of the worker or approval from the [[Philippine Overseas Employment Administration]] (POEA). Contract renewals which used to be automatic now had to be subject to approval of the POEA. ===Aftermath of the deal signing=== Philippine Foreign Affairs Secretary [[Alan Peter Cayetano]] has announced that a new Philippine Ambassador to Kuwait will be appointed and that he will advised Philippine President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to lift the deployment ban of Filipino workers to Kuwait. Duterte on his part has stated that he is open to lifting the ban following the signing of the deal.{{cite news|title=Duterte open to lifting deployment ban in Kuwait|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2018/05/12/Duterte-open-lifting-deployment-ban-Kuwait.html|accessdate=13 May 2018|work=CNN Philippines|date=12 May 2018}} On May 12, 2018, a partial lifting of the ban was announced by the Philippine government allowing the deployment of "skilled" and "semi-skilled" workers to Kuwait{{cite news|last1=Gita|first1=Ruth Abbey|title=Philippines partially lifts Kuwait deployment ban|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/article/1743107/Manila/Local-News/Philippines-partially-lifts-Kuwait-deployment-ban|accessdate=16 May 2018|work=Sun Star Manila|date=15 May 2018}} and Philippine Presidential spokesperson [[Harry Roque]] has stated that relations between the two countries has normalized.{{cite news|title=Duterte orders total lifting of deployment ban to Kuwait|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/05/16/18/duterte-orders-total-lifting-of-deployment-ban-to-kuwait|accessdate=17 May 2018|work=ABS-CBN News|date=16 May 2018}} Duterte ordered the deployment ban to be fully lifted on May 16 and on May 22 he declared that his country's relation with Kuwait is now "okay".{{cite news|title=Duterte thanks Kuwait, says ‘We’re okay now’|url=https://www.untvweb.com/news/duterte-thanks-kuwait-says-were-okay-now/|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=UNTV News and Rescue|date=23 May 2018}} ==See also== *[[Kuwait–Philippines relations]], general international relations between the two countries *[[Sondos Alqattan]], critic of the agreement on migrant domestic workers which ended the diplomatic crisis. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Overseas Filipino Workers}} {{Rodrigo Duterte}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2018 Kuwait-Philippine diplomatic crisis}} [[Category:Kuwait–Philippines relations]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]] [[Category:2018 in the Philippines|Kuwait-Philippine crisis]] [[Category:2018 in Kuwait|Kuwait-Philippine crisis]] [[Category:Human rights in Kuwait]] [[Category:Economic history of Kuwait]] [[Category:Migrant workers]] [[Category:2018 in international relations|Kuwait–Philippine diplomatic crisis]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Infobox mountain pass | name = American Summit | photo = | photo_caption = | elevation_ft = 3652 | elevation_ref = | traversed = [[Taylor Highway]],
[[Valdez-Eagle Trail]] (defunct) | location = Southwest of [[Central, Alaska]], [[Southeast Fairbanks Census Area, Alaska|Southeast Fairbanks Census Area]] | range = [[Mertie Mountains]] | coordinates = {{coord|64.599|N|141.300|W|type:pass_region:US-AK|display=inline,title}} | topo = }} '''American Summit''' or (occasionally) '''American Pass''' is a {{convert|3420|ft|m|0}}-high mountain pass through the high ground of the [[Fortymile River]] district of east-central [[Alaska]].Yukon Quest International. [http://www.yukonquest.com/site/yukon-quest-trail-map/ "Yukon Quest Trail Map/Trail elevations"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107210331/http://www.yukonquest.com/site/yukon-quest-trail-map/ |date=2014-01-07 }}, Yukonquest.com. Accessed March 12, 2009. Today, American Summit is traversed by the [[Taylor Highway]], which connects the town of [[Eagle, Alaska]] to the [[Alaska Highway]] and the [[Top of the World Highway]].Spitzer, Aaron and DuFresne, Jim. [https://books.google.com/books?id=b-JDesZWm5gC ''Alaska'']. Eighth Edition. Lonely Planet, 2006. p. 336. Before the construction of the Taylor Highway in 1953,Ripley, Kate. [https://books.google.com/books?id=SnkfJQT5j24C ''Best Places Alaska: The Locals' Guide to the Best Lodgings, Outdoor Adventures, Sights, Shopping, and Restaurants'']. Third edition. Sasquatch Books, 2003. pp. 100–101. the [[Valdez-Eagle Trail]] passed over American Summit, providing the first overland route between the [[Gulf of Alaska]] and the gold fields of central Alaska.Bureau of Land Management. [http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/etc/medialib/blm/ak/aktest/culture_res/culture_pdfs.Par.42651.File.dat/eagle_valdeztrail_northernportion.pdf "The Eagle-Valdez Trail (Northern Portion)"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318153517/http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/etc/medialib/blm/ak/aktest/culture_res/culture_pdfs.Par.42651.File.dat/eagle_valdeztrail_northernportion.pdf |date=2009-03-18 }} (PDF), BLM.gov. Accessed March 13, 2009. American Summit has been used for thousands of years by [[Athabascan]] natives, who saw its utility as the lowest point in the [[White Mountains (Alaska)|White Mountains]], which lie between the coast of Alaska and the Yukon River. In 1886 and again in 1896, gold was discovered in central Alaska, sparking a [[Klondike Gold Rush|series of gold rushes]] that attracted thousands of miners to the [[Yukon River]] area of Alaska. In 1897, to protect the growing population of the region, the U.S. Army began to establish a series of forts along the Yukon River in order to help maintain order. One of these was [[Fort Egbert]], built in the town of Eagle. Because of its isolated location, supplies for the fort and town had to either travel along the width of Alaska via the Yukon River or through previously established transportation routes in Canada. Seeking a quick all-American route, the U.S. government ordered the construction of a road from [[Valdez, Alaska|Valdez]] on the Gulf of Alaska to Fort Egbert. American Summit, as the lowest point in the mountains separating the two locations, was a natural site for the road, which was completed by 1901. To supply even faster communications, the U.S. military began the construction of [[Washington-Alaska Military Cable and Telegraph System]], of which Eagle would be the northernmost point. Telegraph lines were strung over American Summit in 1902, and an undersea cable connected Valdez to Seattle in 1904. After 1909, when a radio link was established, the telegraph line was abandoned. The road remained and was improved so that by the 1920s, the first automobiles climbed American Summit. In World War II, construction of the Alaska Highway also spurred work on that highway's side roads, and a project to improve the trail was begun in 1945. By 1953, the result was the Taylor Highway, a seasonal route that still connects Eagle to the outside world over American Summit. During the [[2004 Alaska fire season]], the worst in recorded history, American Summit was the site of a {{convert|10000|acre|km2|adj=on}} wildfire,The Associated Press. [http://cms.firehouse.com/web/online/Wildland-Firefighting/Alaskan-Fires-Blacken-More-Than-80-000 Acres/4$31915 "Alaskan Fires Blacken More Than 80,000 Acres"]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, cms.firehouse.com. June 22, 2004. Accessed March 13, 2009. one of several hundred that ultimately consumed {{convert|6600000|acre|km2}} in Alaska that year. Today, Eagle is an alcohol-free town, and American Summit is notable as the location of the liquor store nearest to Eagle. The store has been called one of the most remote liquor stores in the world. The [[Yukon Quest]] {{convert|1000|mi|km|adj=on}} sled dog race crosses Eagle Summit every February on its route between [[Fairbanks, Alaska]], and [[Whitehorse, Yukon]]. == Notes == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/etc/medialib/blm/ak/fdo.Par.10476.Image.-1.-1.1.jpg Map of the Taylor Highway with facilities and hiking trails highlighted] [[Category:Mountain passes of Alaska]] [[Category:Landforms of Southeast Fairbanks Census Area, Alaska]] [[Category:Yukon Quest]]

{{italic title}} '''''Aristo''''' is a 2008 play by American born playwright [[Martin Sherman]], based on material in the book ''[[Nemesis (Peter Evans novel)|Nemesis]]''<ref>http://www.harpercollins.com/books/9780061155208/Nemesis/index.aspx</ref> by [[Peter J. Evans|Peter Evans]] about the life of [[Aristotle Onassis]] after he met Jackie Kennedy. It premiered at the [[Minerva Theatre, Chichester]] (11 September – 11 October 2008), was directed by [[Nancy Meckler]] and starred [[Robert Lindsay (actor)|Robert Lindsay]] as Onassis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cft.org.uk/cft-productions_details.asp?pid%3D181 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091104160640/http://www.cft.org.uk/cft-productions_details.asp?pid=181 |archivedate=2009-11-04 |df= }}</ref>
==Reviews== The play was poorly received by critics and did not transfer to the [[West End theatre|West End]] even though it had sold out in Chichester. However, critics agreed that [[Robert Lindsay (actor)|Robert Lindsay]]'s performance eclipsed the play.<ref>http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/reviews/article-1067093/Aristo-Onassis-original-babe-magnet.html</ref><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2008/oct/03/theatre1</ref><ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/culturecritics/charlesspencer/3561567/Aristo-tiresome-lesson-in-ancient-Greek.html</ref>
==Cast== *[[Robert Lindsay (actor)|Robert Lindsay]] - Onassis *[[Elizabeth McGovern]] - Jacqueline *June Watson - Eleni *[[Robin Soans]] - Costa *[[Denise Black]] - Dimitra *Julius D'Silva - Theo *John Hodgkinson - Yanni *[[Diana Quick]] - Maria *Joe Marsh - Alexander *Ben Grove - Musician *[[Graeme Taylor]] - Musician *Andrew Elias - Waiter *Nick Howard-Brown - Waiter
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aristo (Play)}} [[Category:2008 plays]] [[Category:Plays based on books]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays based on real people]] [[Category:Plays set in the 1960s]] [[Category:Plays set in the 1970s]] [[Category:Plays set in Greece]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Aristotle Onassis]] [[Category:Plays by Martin Sherman]]

The '''Bals des victimes''', or victims' balls, were [[Ball (dance)|balls]] that were said to have been put on by [[dance|dancing]] societies after the [[Reign of Terror]]. To be admitted to these societies and balls, one had to be a near relative of someone who had been [[guillotine]]d during the Terror. The balls came to prominence after the death of [[Maximilien Robespierre|Robespierre]], supposedly first being held in early 1795 and first mentioned in popular writing in 1797.<ref name="Schechter">Ronald Schechter, "Gothic Thermidor: The Bals des victimes, the Fantastic, and the Production of Historical Knowledge in Post-Terror France," ''Representations'', No. 61, (Winter, 1998), pp. 78, 79.</ref> While anecdotal evidence<ref>''The Times'', 29 July 1797, p. 3: "Great dissentions having taken place respecting etiquette and precedency at the ''Victims Ball'' at Paris, it has been determined that the ''Guillotine'' should have the first rank, and open the ball..."</ref> attests to the balls' occurrence, and generations of French and non-French historians described them and accepted them as fact, some recent scholarship, citing a near-total lack of primary evidence, argues that they may have been fabrications based on rumor.<ref name="Schechter" /> Historian David Bell concludes: "The ''bals des victimes''... never took place — they were an invention of early nineteenth-century Romantic authors."<ref>David A. Bell, ''The First Total War'' (Houghton Mifflin, 2007), p. 192.</ref>
The ''bals des victimes'' allegedly began as part of a rash of merrymaking and balls that broke out as the Terror came to an end. According to one source, they emerged as an idea of youths whose parents and other near relatives had gone to the guillotine, and to whom the revolution had now restored their relatives' confiscated property. Reveling in the return of fortune they established aristocratic, decadent balls open to themselves alone.<ref>[[Octave Uzanne]], ''The Frenchwoman of the Century'' (London, J.C. Nimmo, 1886), pp. 9-12. [https://books.google.com/books?id=VMwBAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22the+frenchwoman+of+the+century%22&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=ieF_qPvJ1a&sig=asFGuv4bkWzrRdKWBwBRMl-irww#PPA12,M1]</ref>
Descriptions of the balls' particulars vary, but the common thread is that they were a [[catharsis|cathartic]] device in which the participants [[acting out|acted out]] the emotional impact of their relatives' [[execution]]s and the social upheavals occurring as a result of the revolution. Many who described the balls, often generations afterwards, nevertheless found them a scandalous idea. Whether real or imagined, the very idea of the balls reflected the post-Terror generations' morbid fascination with the horror of the guillotine and the excesses of the [[French Revolution]] with its mass executions.
Those who attended the orgiastic balls reportedly wore mourning clothes or elaborate costumes with crepe armbands signifying mourning. Some accounts have both men and women wearing plain but scanty dress in the wake of the impoverishment of the Revolution,<ref name="Jackson">Lady Catherine Hannah Charlotte Jackson, ''The French Court and Society: Reign of Louis XVI and First Empire'', vol. 2 (London, Richard Bentley & Son, 1881), 207-210, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pkg2AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA208&lpg=PA208&dq=guillotine+%22bals+des+victimes%22&source=web&ots=9lbU2QfMF4&sig=daGgjEF691QLR8mwKYp15QBuzpQ#PPA210,M1]</ref> at least until the return of their fortunes at which time ball dress became highly elaborate.<ref name="Uzanne12">Octave Uzanne, ''The Frenchwoman of the Century'' (London, J.C. Nimmo, 1886), p. 12. [https://books.google.com/books?id=VMwBAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22the+frenchwoman+of+the+century%22&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=ieF_qPvJ1a&sig=asFGuv4bkWzrRdKWBwBRMl-irww#PPA12,M1]</ref> Others describe women, in the fashion of [[Incroyables and Merveilleuses|Merveilleuses]],<ref>Thomas Carlyle,''The French Revolution: A History'', vol.3 (Leipzig: Bernhard Tauchnitz, 1851), Bk. 7, Ch. 2, 347-50. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3DYLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA349&dq=merveilleuses+french+revolution+sandals&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDgoyVoKfPAhUCKB4KHf1RA9gQ6AEIHjAA#v=onepage&q=merveilleuses%20french%20revolution%20sandals&f=false]</ref> dressing scandalously in Greco-Roman attire, with their feet bare, in sandals, or adorned only by ribbons,<ref>"The Tragedy of the Temple," ''Catholic World'' 21 (April-Sept. 1875), pp. 227-28 [https://books.google.com/books?id=WmYrmky-DNQC&pg=RA1-PA228&lpg=RA1-PA228&dq=guillotine+%22bals+des+victimes%22&source=web&ots=2YHvtshJhj&sig=NQLQSnOwwntbd0zkivgrM93J5Bk#PRA1-PA227,M1]</ref> a possible allusion to the fact that women often went barefoot to the guillotine.<ref>[https://versaillesgossip.wordpress.com/2012/09/03/womens-fashions-under-the-influence-of-guillotine/ "Women's Fashions Under the Influence of Guillotine,"]</ref> The style of dress at such a ball was known by some as the "''costume à la victime''."<ref name="Jackson"/> Women, and by some accounts men too, wore a red ribbon or string around their necks at the point of a guillotine blade's impact. Both men and women attending the balls were said to have worn or cut their hair in a fashion that bared their necks in a manner reflecting the haircut given the victim by the executioner, women often using a comb known as a cadenette to achieve this fashion.<ref>Lady Catherine Hannah Charlotte Jackson, ''The French Court and Society: Reign of Louis XVI and First Empire'', vol. 2 (London, Richard Bentley & Son, 1881), 207, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pkg2AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA208&lpg=PA208&dq=guillotine+%22bals+des+victimes%22&source=web&ots=9lbU2QfMF4&sig=daGgjEF691QLR8mwKYp15QBuzpQ#PPA210,M1]</ref> According to some, this was the origin of the feminine hairstyle known as the "''coiffure à la victime''" or more popularly the "''coiffure à la Titus''",<ref>Octave Uzanne, ''The Frenchwoman of the Century'' (London, J.C. Nimmo, 1886), pp. 13-14. [https://books.google.com/books?id=VMwBAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22the+frenchwoman+of+the+century%22&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=ieF_qPvJ1a&sig=asFGuv4bkWzrRdKWBwBRMl-irww#PPA12,M1]</ref> or (in England) "''a la guillotine''".<ref>''The Times'', 9 September 1796, p. 2: "The Ladies who turn up their hair behind, ''a la guillotine'', wish, no doubt, to impress their suitors..."</ref> Some sources state that a woman sporting this hairstyle sometimes wore a red shawl or throat ribbon even when not attending a ''bal des victimes''.
In another macabre touch, instead of a graceful bow or bob of the head to one's dancing partner, a man who attended a ''bal des victimes'' would jerk his head sharply downwards in imitation of the moment of [[decapitation]].<ref name="Uzanne12" /> Some sources suggest that women, too, adopted this salutation.<ref>Franðcois Gendron, ''The Gilded Youth of Thermidor'' (Montreal: McGill-Queen's University Press, 1993), p. 32. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Lp2tlV5sHMgC&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=%22bals+des+victimes%22&source=web&ots=AXKcDsYJWO&sig=w67a6nhQmfcnfm4_3nF-_Fsk0Ys#PPA32,M1]</ref>
==See also==
*[[Thermidorian Reaction]] *[[Hôtel Thellusson]], where bals des victimes were organized *[[Incroyables and Merveilleuses]] *[[The French Revolution: A History]] *[[Jules Michelet]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
* Joseph Clarke, ''Commemorating the Dead in Revolutionary France: Revolution and Remembrance, 1789-1799'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007). * Katell Le Bourhis, ''Age of Napoleon: Costume from Revolution to Empire, 1789-1815'' (New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1990). * Aileen Ribeiro, ''Fashion in the French Revolution'' (New York: Holmes & Meier, 1988).
[[Category:1795 events of the French Revolution]] [[Category:Balls in France]] [[Category:European court festivities]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} '''Black Friday''' ({{lang-dv|ކަޅު ހުކުރު}}), August 13, 2004, was the crackdown by the Maldivian [[National Security Service (Maldives)|National Security Service (NSS)]] — later [[Maldivian National Defence Force]] — on a peaceful [[protest]]<ref>[http://news.amnesty.org/index/ENGASA290042004 http://news.amnesty.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050307022309/http://news.amnesty.org/index/ENGASA290042004 |date=March 7, 2005 }} Nature of demonstration as defined by Amnesty</ref> in the capital city of [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. This unplanned and unorganized [[Demonstration (people)|demonstration]] was the largest such protest in the country's history. Beginning on the evening of August 12, 2004, the demonstration grew and continued until it was forcefully ended on the afternoon of August 13, 2004. Protesters initially demanding the freeing of the pro-reformists arrested on the afternoon of August 12, 2004. As the protest continued to grow, people demanded the resignation of president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]], who had been in power since 1978. What started as a peaceful demonstration ended after 22 hours, as the country's darkest day in recent history. Several people were severely injured as NSS personnel used riot batons and teargas on unarmed [[civilians]].
Pursuant to the powers vested in him by Section 144 of the [[Constitution of the Maldives|Constitution]] — and for only the second time in Maldives history — president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]] declared a [[State of Emergency]] in [[Malé]] and the nearby islands a few minutes after the crackdown. Several members of the [[Majlis]], former cabinet ministers, and many [[reformists]] were arrested. As a symbol of unity, President Gayoom pardoned all arrested following the [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on the Maldives|December 26th tsunami]].
==Demonstration== [[Image:Black friday gathering.png|right|thumb|300px|Map indicating the crowd gathering]] When police summoned Mr. Mohamed Yusuf, a few reform activists decided to gather near [[Republican Square]] to inquire about Yoosuf's detention. What started as a vigil at Republican Square in Malé at dusk on August 12, 2004, turned into a mass gathering of people demanding democratic reform.
As the crowd grew larger and the demands to free Mr. Yoosuf became louder, he was released that afternoon. However, the protesters demanded four other reformists detained in Dhoonidhoo detention centre be transferred to Malé. They also called for the release of Naushad Waheed, Ahmed Didi, [[Mohamed Zaki]] and Fathimath Nisreen; all of whom were, according to the Opposition movement, detained without a fair trial. By early morning August 13, 2004, a large crowd had gathered near Republican Square, the NSS building and [[Shaheed Hussain Adam Building]]. Initially the NSS and government minister [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] unsuccessfully tried to win the trust of the crowd by addressing the crowd over a [[megaphone]]. When they failed, they asked the pro-reformist MP [[Ibrahim Ismail (politician)|Ibrahim Ismail]] (Ibra) to address the crowd in front of the NSS building. He convinced the crowd to move into nearby Republican Square. Senior MDP activist [[Muad Mohamed Zaki]] who was in the front row of the protest blocking the NSS building tried to discourage protestors from moving their position.
After moving the crowd into Republican Square, Ibrahim Ismail addressed the crowd and assured them he would take their demands to the NSS authorities for their consideration. The crowd then gave its demands to Ibrahim Ismail, which were:
*Release of the detained reformists *Release of [[Sandhaanu]] prisoners (Writers of an Internet magazine) *Release of [[Naushad Waheed]] ([[Artist]] and reformist) *Resignation of the President [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]] *Resignation of [[Yameen Abdul Gayoom]] (Minister of Trade and brother of Gayoom) *Resignation of [[Abdullah Hameed]] (Minister of Atolls and brother of Gayoom)
In the early morning, the reformists were released. They came directly from the Dhoonidhoo detention centre to Republican Square. There they addressed the crowd, criticized [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]] and called for his resignation. They also demanded the demonstration be reported live on state run television and radio. However, no news of the protest was transmitted yet. The crowd continued to grow and "took (on) a life of its own", as later described by Ibrahim Ismail in his interview on the [[BBC]].{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
At around 0700 hrs [[Maafushi Prison]] was broken, thinking the government was overthrown, as the detainees got the news of the unusual protest in [[Malé]]. They headed to Malé in two [[Dhoni]]s. However they were intercepted by the NSS coastguard. One of the Dhonis was sunk and the other gassed with tear gas.
==Crackdown== {{unreferenced section|date=August 2014}} As the calling for [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom|Gayoom]]'s [[resignation]] got louder and stronger, a few pro-government people gathered to [[Republican Square]]. Some of them were sent there, according to reformists, to create [[violence]] so that use of force to disperse the [[crowd]] could be justified. Since international [[Mass media|media]] was reporting the event, [[National Security Service (Maldives)|NSS]] needed a valid and justifiable reason to use force to disperse the crowd. In several occasions the pro-government crowd tried to instigate violence. However reformists ignored them and continued the demonstration, calling for the resignation.
At around 0830hrs, a person named Hussain Yoosuf stabbed two police officers. He is one of the many people who testified before the [[committee|commission]] established to investigate the death of [[Evan Naseem]]. After this incident there was a report of fire in the nearby [[Huravee Building]], a government office building. NSS blamed the crowd for starting the fire. In addition to this, there came a group of people who threw bottles and other objects towards the Police Headquarters. The [[protesters]] tried to stop them without any success. Police blamed reformists for these activities and portrayed them as a violent [[Angry mob|mob]].
After Friday prayers, at around 1430hrs NSS issued final warning to the crowd. However they refuse to leave the Republican square. Using the previously described commotion as an excuse, the riot police pounced on the protesters, beat them brutally with [[Baton (law enforcement)|truncheon]]s and arrested a number of protesters. Women were also beaten with truncheons and they sustained severe injuries. Ambulances were rushed to the hospital with casualties. [[Tear gas]] was used on the crowd at around 1500hrs. Senior MDP member [[Muad Mohamed Zaki]] was violently beaten by seven NSS officers with wooden planks in broad daylight as he was dragged to the NSS Headquarters. This alerted the British Parliament and European Union officials that Muad was communicating closely with while he staying in the UK representing [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and working to free Sandhaanu political prisoners in Maldives. Thousands of protestors were blindfolded, handcuffed and beaten on that day as law and order seemed to have temporarily disappeared.
==State of Emergency== President [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]] declared a [[State of Emergency]] in [[Malé]] and nearby islands, pursuant to powers vested in him by Section 144 of the Constitution, for the second time in the Maldives history. A curfew was imposed in Malé with heavy security. There were several roadblocks and check posts.
After nearly two months, the State of Emergency was lifted due to International pressure. {{Clear}}
==Internet and SMS service taken offline== [[Dhiraagu]] and Focus Infocom was forced to shut down Internet and [[Short message service|SMS]] services to prevent the images, video and news of the event leaking to international media. However the events were covered and the images did leak to media despite these preventive measurements.
==Local media reporting== Both ''[[Television Maldives]] (TVM)'' and ''Voice of Maldives (VOM)'', controlled by the government, initially did not report the event as a major event. At 1400hrs news, while the protest was still going, TVM reported that "only a small crowd had gathered and caused disharmony at the Republican Square, the people who caused this had been noted and that action will be taken against them". At 2000hrs news, after declaring the [[State of Emergency]], TVM downplayed the size of the protesters, and called the gathering "illegal in every possible sense".{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
Special programs were aired on Radio and Television to cover-up the real reason behind the protest. It was portrayed by the local media to be a violent mob that attacked police building, government properties and attack police officers. One sided, biased reporting was aired for weeks on the local media.
==One year anniversary demonstration== {{Main|2005 Maldives civil unrest}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Black friday anniversary2.jpg|thumb|500px|right|People gathered to demonstrate; Few minutes before [[Mohamed Nasheed]] and others literally dragged into NSS headquarters. [[media:Black friday anniversary2.jpg|Full view]]]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Balck friday anniversary1.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Members of [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] sitting in Republican Square, shortly before being "dragged" into NSS headquarters, August 12, 2005]] -->
On August 12, 2005, to mark the first [[anniversary]] of the Black Friday, members of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and pro-[[reformists]] started gathering near Republican Square. Despite heavy police and [[National Security Service (Maldives)|NSS]] presence, at around 4:30pm local time [[Mohamed Nasheed]] - Chairman of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party|MDP]] - along with other several leading members of the party, decided to gather at Republican square. Security was tight around [[Malé]] due to the obvious perceptibility of such a demonstration to mark this anniversary. Two days before, on August 10, 2005, NSS announced that they will be conducting a huge training exercise in Malé for four days, starting from August 11, 2005.
Despite heavy police presence, [[Mohamed Nasheed]] decided to sit right in the center of the Republican Square with his colleagues. Minutes later he was approached by a team of [[Maldives Police Service]]. They approached him and asked him to simply "go away" from there. Nasheed demanded to know why he was asked to leave while he is not committing anything [[Law|illegal]]. The leader of this team responded by saying such gatherings are illegal and they will have to remove him by [[force]] if not obeyed within five minutes. To this [[ultimatum]], Nasheed responded by saying. "You will give us five minutes, after that, what? You will beat us to death?"{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} At one time Nasheed asked the police to join them, since he is not [[inciting]] [[violence]] but [[peace]]fully sitting there. Since he refused to leave the spot, the police team moved towards the [[flag]] pole few meters away.
At around 4:23pm, [[riot police]] moved into Republican Square. Soon they surrounded [[Mohamed Nasheed]] along with other members of the party, present with him. Nasheed and his colleagues still refused to stand up. Members of riot police then forcefully removed them and had them taken into the nearby NSS headquarters. This led to [[2005 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in Malé and some other atolls]], that lasted for three nights. The unrest was controlled and several people were arrested.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050412152227/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/blackfridayalbum/ Photo album] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050316152239/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/blackfridayalbum/blackfridayinmaldives.htm More photos of Black Friday] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141006193115/http://blackfridaydeals2014x.com/ Black Friday deals 2014 Walmart] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060307225502/http://news.amnesty.org/index/ENGASA290042004 Amnesty International press release] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/3561340.stm BBC reporting] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110926234806/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/news/eyewitness_account.htm Eyewitness account] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070207090707/http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/1011/ Censorship in the Maldives]
===First anniversary related=== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051201001659/http://minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=1067 Significant events in chronological order] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051210051242/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/Album13082005/index.htm Photos] * ''Blog posts (Content may not be neutral)'' [http://freethemaldives.blogspot.com/2005/08/black-friday-revisited-repeat.html] [http://freethemaldives.blogspot.com/2005/08/black-friday-ii-freedom-vs-n-ss.html] * [http://blackfriday-deals.info/ Black Friday Deals]
