revision.comment: The penile tourniquet - Please see discussion of this WP article, there I mentioned several sources
revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = {{PAGENAME}} | synonyms = | image = Hairtournequet.JPG | alt = | caption = Hair tourniquet | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Hair tourniquet''' is a medical condition wherein a hair or other thread becomes tied around a toe or finger or male genital tightly, so as to put the digit at risk of damage. Occasionally, this is known as ''toe [[tourniquet]]''.
The problem usually arises in babies and small children when hairs and thread are lost loosely inside socks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1348969-overview|last=Cardriche|first=Dennis|title=Hair Tourniquet Removal|work=medscape.com |accessdate=25 May 2011}}</ref> They can become spontaneously tied round a toe and will tend to tighten with wriggling. Natural [[hair]] is much more likely to undergo this phenomenon than spun thread.
Incidents similar to this can also occur during sleep, usually under [[duvet]]s or sheets which have loose threads which can constrict the toes.
==Signs== As this is a condition primarily of young children, symptoms are rarely reported. The child will become suddenly uncomfortable and miserable. As the digit is often inside a sock, the cause may not be clear.
The affected toe can no longer receive an adequate blood supply via the [[arteries]], nor can blood be drained via the [[veins]]. The toe will therefore swell and turn blue, indicating [[ischemia]].
The ligature will not stretch in response to the toe swelling and will therefore cut into the skin in more severe cases, like a cheese-wire.
==Treatment== [[File:Hair Tourniquet after.JPG|thumb|A toe freed of a hair tourniquet. The toe has had to be cut longitudinally to divide the hair]] The ligature is cut or dissolved as quickly as possible. Often it is possible to lift a portion of it to enable cutting, but in a severe case the ligature must be cut through the skin. This is, of course, injurious to the child, but may prevent loss of the digit. It must take place on the side of the toe, where there are no nerves or tendons.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Sivathasan|first=Niroshan|last2=Vijayarajan|first2=Lavnya|date=2012|title=Hair-Thread Tourniquet Syndrome: A Case Report and Literature Review|url=http://www.hindawi.com/journals/crim/2012/171368/|journal=Case Reports in Medicine|language=en|volume=2012|pages=1–4|doi=10.1155/2012/171368|issn=1687-9627}}</ref>
Other treatment not requiring minor surgery includes use of a chemical [[depilatory]], such as the over-the-counter product [[Nair (hair removal)|Nair]], to dissolve or weaken the hair. This option is not indicated if the hair tourniquet has cut into the skin. Use of depilatory products such as Nair is not an effective treatment on nylon or other fibers that are not human hair.<ref name=":0" />
==Prognosis== Despite the distressing nature of the condition, outcomes are excellent. Loss of the toe is extremely rare, as is any residual disability. In rare cases the loss of a digit is possible. Rubber bands can have the same effect.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== * [[Tourniquet]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Infants and their care}}
[[Category:Injuries]] [[Category:Infancy]] [[Category:Safety]]

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=January 2011}} {{advert|date=January 2011}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox Radio show |show_name = Hot30 Countdown |image = [[File:Hot30 Countdown Logo.png|220px]] |imagesize = |caption = |other_names = |format = [[Contemporary hit radio]] |runtime = 2.5 hours (7:30 P.M. – 10:00 P.M. AEST) |country = Australia |language = [[English language|English]] |home_station = [[2Day FM]] |syndicates = [[Fox FM (Melbourne)|Fox FM]]
[[B105 FM]]
[[SAFM]]
[[92.9 (Perth radio station)|92.9]]
[[NXFM]]
[[104.7 (Canberra)|104.7 FM]]
[[Ace Radio|Ace Radio Network]] (Regional Victoria) |television = |presenter = [[Mike Christian|Michael Christian]] (MC) (2012)
[[Mel Greig]] (2012) |starring = |announcer = |creator = |writer = |director = |senior_editor = |editor = |producer = |exec_producer = |narrated = |rec_location = |first_aired = 1996 |last_aired = 2012 |num_series = |num_episodes = |audio_format = [[Stereophonic sound|Stereo]] |opentheme = |othertheme = |endtheme = |website = |podcast = }} The '''''Hot30 Countdown''''' was an [[Australia]]n radio show hosted by [[Mike Christian]] (MC) and [[Mel Greig]]. It was broadcast on the [[Today Network]] from the studios of [[2Day FM]] in [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] to every [[States and territories of Australia|state]] and the [[Australian Capital Territory]] following 'The Dirt'. It was cancelled on 10 December 2012, following the [[death of Jacintha Saldanha]]. ==History== Established in 1996, the show was first hosted by [[Ugly Phil]] and [[Jackie O (radio host)|Jackie O]] under the name "Ugly Phil's Hot 30". Brisbane-based announcer, [[Kyle Sandilands]], was then moved in to host with Jackie O until 2003. Labrat and Alexis took over the ''Hot30 Countdown'' from 2004 after Sandilands and Jackie O moved to the drive-time slot. A previously unknown announcer "Higgo" stepped in after Labrat took the morning shift on [[2DayFM]]. Alexis and Higgo hosted the nightly show until 2005, when [[Craig Low|Craig "Lowie" Low]] came in to host the program until mid-2006. Low occasionally included Carla "Biggzy" Bignasca as co-host who was the [[executive producer]] of the show from the middle of 2006. ''Hot30 Countdown'' phased out the national promotion of the Black Thunders in early 2005, across the Today Network. Sam "Sam Mac" McMillan and Bignasca hosted the show from late 2006 until early 2007. From early 2007 Tim Lee was announced as the permanent replacement to host the show with Bignasca. In February 2010, it was announced that Lee and Bignasca would be leaving the ''Hot30 Countdown'', with Lee relocating to [[Fox FM (Melbourne)|Fox FM]] in Melbourne, presenting Mornings; while Bignasca expected to focus on television opportunities. Lee and Bignasca presented their last show on Friday 12 March 2010. Austereo announced on 10 March 2010 that [[Charli Robinson]] and [[Chris Page]] would be the new hosts.{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/14321/20100423-1020/youthweek.com/2010/whos-on-board/ambassadors/charli-and-chris.html | url = http://youthweek.com/2010/whos-on-board/ambassadors/charli-and-chris.html | title = Hot 30 Hosts – Charli Delaney and Chris Page | archivedate = 23 April 2010 | publisher = National Youth Week 2010 | accessdate = 21 May 2017 }} They commenced on 15 March, subsequently introducing a new show at 7pm, ''The Dirt''. Page left the ''Hot30 Countdown'' at the end of 2010, moving to [[2MMM|Triple M]]'s ''[[Grill Team]]'' in Sydney and Delaney became the first solo host of ''The Dirt'' nationally. In February 2011, Austereo announced that Matty Acton and Maude Garrett would be the new hosts. From 5 September 2011, it was announced by Southern Cross Austereo, the ''Hot30 Countdown'' would broadcast into syndicated channels as well as additional Today Network regional channels and with the merger it changed their Australian studio line to 13 10 60. Acton and Garrett also hosted a weekend music show on Southern Cross Ten which was launched as ''Hot30 Countdown TV'', airing Saturdays from 10{{nbsp}}am to 12{{nbsp}}noon and Sundays at 9{{nbsp}}am to 12{{nbsp}}noon.{{cite web |url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-news/media/2011/08/26/hot30-countdown-launches-broadcast-additions/ |title=Hot30 Countdown launches broadcast additions |last1=Reid |first1=Poppy |date=29 August 2011 |work=themusicnetwork.com |publisher= |accessdate=7 December 2012}} On 31 January 2012 Garrett revealed on the show that she was leaving on 10 February and it was announced on Friday 9 March that [[Mel Greig]] (of ''Amazing Race Australia'') would be the replacement co-host.{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/124103/20120403-0148/www.throng.com.au/amazing-race-australia/amazing-race-australias-mel-greig-lands-hot30-gig.html | url = http://www.throng.com.au/amazing-race-australia/amazing-race-australias-mel-greig-lands-hot30-gig.html | title = ''Amazing Race Australia''{{'}}s Mel Greig lands Hot30 gig | last = Lawdon | first = Courtney | archivedate = 3 April 2012 | date = 10 March 2012 | work = Throng | accessdate = 21 May 2017 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/confidential/mel-greig-leaves-for-hot-job-at-30/story-e6fredq3-1226295419838 |title=Mel Greig leaves for hot new job at 30 |last1=Leo |first1=Jessica |date=9 March 2012 |work=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |publisher= |accessdate=7 December 2012}} In November Acton announced that he was leaving the show to work at Sea FM on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Queensland]] with [[Fox FM (Melbourne)|Fox FM]] morning presenter, [[Mike Christian]] (MC) replacing Acton in early December. ===Duchess of Cambridge prank call and cancellation=== {{main|Death of Jacintha Saldanha}} On 6 December 2012, the day after the then pregnant [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], was admitted to King Edward VII's Hospital for a severe case of [[morning sickness]], Mel Greig and Michael Christian rang the hospital pretending to be [[Queen Elizabeth II]] and [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]]. The prank worked, with a nurse, [[Death of Jacintha Saldanha|Jacintha Saldanha]], forwarding the call on to Catherine's private nurse, and Greig and Christian were able to obtain Catherine's medical details.{{cite web | url = http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/mel-greig-and-michael-christian-interviewed-on-tv-over-death-of-jacintha-saldanha/news-story/fd47684bb4445881edc170b23ba6fcbd?nk=b68900f0e6f4d31930789e58d3a349d5-1495348312 | title = Hospital hoax nurse Jacintha Saldanha's mother inconsolable | last1 = Michael | first1 = Sarah | last2 = Lees | first2 = Justin | date = 11 December 2012 | work = [[The Herald Sun]] | publisher = [[News Corp Australia]] | accessdate = 21 May 2017 }} The prank was condemned by a journalist writing in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', and the hospital announced they deeply regretted the incident and would be "reviewing [their] telephone protocols."{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/05/kate-middleton-pregnant-hospital-nurse-radio_n_2243362.html?ir=Style |title=Kate Middleton Hospital Prank: Nurse Fooled By Radio Show Into Divulging Duchess' Details |last1=Adams |first1=Rebecca |date=5 December 2012|work=[[The Huffington Post]] |publisher= |accessdate=7 December 2012}} Following the incident Saldanha was found dead in a suspected suicide.{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/07/kate-middleton-nurse-found-dead-prank-callers_n_2257231.html#slide=1833628 |title=Kate Middleton's Hospital Nurse Found Dead In London Days After Being Duped By Prank Callers |last1=Krupnick |first1=Ellie |last2=Misener |first2=Jessica |date=7 December 2012|work=[[The Huffington Post]] |publisher= |accessdate=7 December 2012}} Following her death both Greig and Christian, took down their [[Twitter]] accounts. An executive producer for 2Day FM, told [[TMZ (website)|TMZ]], "I advise you to stop trying to call them" as the hosts have been "ordered" not to speak to media. It was later announced that Greig and Christian would be stepping away from their duties. The company that owned the station released a statement reported by TMZ, which stated, "SCA and 2Day FM are deeply saddened by the tragic news of the death of nurse Jacintha Saldanha from King Edward VII’s Hospital. [...] SCA and the hosts have decided that they will not return to their radio show until further notice out of respect for what can only be described as a tragedy." At a [[Australian Federal Court|Federal Court]] hearing it became known that Australian media watchdog [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] (ACMA) had prepared a confidential, preliminary report saying that the Radio Royal hoax 'broke law'. 2Day FM acted illegally by airing the phone call without consent.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-24172564 |title=Radio Royal hoax 'broke law' according to watchdog |date=20 September 2013|work=[[BBC]]|publisher= |accessdate=20 September 2013}} On 10 December 2012, Southern Cross Austereo, announced that the show would be cancelled effective immediately.{{cite web |url=http://southerncrossaustereo.com.au/pdf/Southern-Cross-Austereo-Media-Statement-10122012.pdf |title=Southern Cross Austereo Press Release |last1= |first1= |date=10 December 2012 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=10 December 2012}} On the following day both Christian and Greig were interviewed on TV shows and apologised for their part in the incident. == Timeline of hosts and co-hosts == * 1996–1999: [[Ugly Phil]]'s Hot 30 with [[Jackie O (radio host)|Jackie O]] * 1999–2000: Ugly Phil and Jackie O * 2000–2003: [[Kyle & Jackie O|Kyle and Jackie O]] * 2004-2004: Labrat and Alexis * 2004–2005: Higgo and Alexis * 2005–2006: Lowie with Maz Compton for the first half of 2005, Lowie's show solo, then with Biggzy mid-2006 * 2006–2007: Sam Mac and Biggzy (Carla Bignasca) * 2007–2010: Tim Lee and Biggzy (Carla Bignasca) * 2010: [[Charli Robinson|Charli Delaney]] and Pagey (Chris Page) * 2011: Matty Acton and [[Maude Garrett]] * 2012: Matty Acton and [[Mel Greig]] * 2012: [[Mike Christian|Michael Christian]] (MC) and Mel Greig === ''Hot30 Jelli'' === {{main|Choose The Hits}} In November 2009, a [[Digital Radio]] offshoot, ''Hot30 Jelli'', was launched.{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignbrief.com/wa/2009/10/second-dab-digital-station-for.html |title=Second DAB+ digital station for Austereo |date=21 October 2009 |work=campaignbrief.com |publisher= |accessdate=7 December 2012}} A joint venture with [[Jelli]], the station uses a play list from current and previous ''Hot30 Countdown'' music, which is then voted on by listeners at the ''Hot30 Jelli'' website. The station has since been renamed [[Choose The Hits]]. == References == == External links == *[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/2013/01/28/11/12/royal-hoax-pranksters-off-air-for-good 'Royal hoax pranksters off air for good' news article ninemsn] *[https://www.facebook.com/BumpShow Replacement ''The Bump Show''] on [[Facebook]] *[http://www.bumpshow.com.au/ Replacement ''The Bump Show'' website] *[https://twitter.com/bumpshow/ Replacement ''The Bump Show''] on [[Twitter]] [[Category:1999 radio programme debuts]] [[Category:Australian radio programs]] [[Category:Music chart shows]] [[Category:2012 controversies]] [[Category:2012 radio programme endings]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} '''InProg''' is an international [[progressive rock]] [[rock festival|festival]] held almost yearly since 2001 in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]].
The festival was organised by the Russian [[Rock (music)|Rock]]-magazine [[InRock]].
The whole reason for the original festival came to be the visit of [[Azazello (band)|Azazello]] to [[Norway]]. [[Azazello (band)|Azazello]] played on a [[Norway]] festival with [[Wild Willy]]'s Gang (coverband featuring [[Willy Bendiksen]] and [[Jorn Lande]]). [[Azazello (band)|Azazello]] stopped in [[Moscow]] for a while so a concert with other bands was held. Responses were very good so it was decided to make it annual. However, because December isn't the best time for a festival it was moved to the beginning of the year, therefore year 2002 was skipped.
Most of the performers in this [[rock festival|festival]] are [[progressive rock]] artists from [[Russia]], but there are [[progressive rock]] artists from other countries too. The idea is to put well-known artists and unknown artists in the same concerts so more bands will gain recognition.
The organizers of this [[rock festival|festival]] called it "a festival of intellectual music", because except giving to [[progressive rock]] artists to perform they also give to [[Jazz]] and other genre artists to perform. The official slogan of the festival is "Music for the brains".
Since the [[rock festival|festival]] began in 2001 its popularity grew from year to year.
Since 2004 the [[rock festival|festival]] was taking place in the biggest [[Moscow]] rock-clubs, B2 in 2004 and 2006, and Apelsin club in 2005.
In the year 2005 the festival turned into an international two-day [[rock festival|festival]], with legendary [[progressive rock]] bands not only from [[Russia]] but from other countries to coming to perform in the [[rock festival|festival]].
Though there was an InProg 2007 festival planned, it did not take place because of a low financial situation.
In 2008, after kind invitation of "[[Empty Hills]]" festival, larges uncommercial open air festival in Russia, InProg re-emerged as "InProg on the Hills", sort of "festival in festival". It took one evening on one stage ("Empty Hills" was 4 days and 4 stages with all kinds of different non-commercial music from blues and folk rock to rock-underground, jazz/fusion, progressive...).
And finally, upon finally getting a sponsor - Danish footwear company [[ECCO|Ecco]], InProg organizers decided to change its name for "[[Ecco Prog Fest]]". First "Ecco Prog" took place at 29 November 2008 in familiar "B2 Club", Moscow, with Swedish [[Flower Kings]] as headliners. Russian bands this times were [[Apple Pie (band)|Apple Pie]] from Kursk, [[Batisfera]] and [[Kostarev Group]] from Moscow.
"InProg on the Hills" was to continue on "Empty Hills'2009" festival. There was big progressive rock section planned, consisting Kostarev Group, Vespero, Jazzator, Disen Gage, Rada & Ternovnik, Symfusion Orchestra, Lost World, Apple Pie, The Worm Ouroboros, Aziris, Vespero. However, festival was nearly cancelled due to logistical problems caused by heavy rains. Most of planned bands were told to stay at home and only 3 bands were able to come to the festival location and play: Kostarev Group & Jazzator (12 June) and Vespero (13 June). Disen Gage first planned to arrive, but eventually things didn't work out.
2009th [[Ecco Prog Fest]] was planned at 24 October at "Yauza Palace", Moscow. However, because of financial reasons it was reverted to InProg Festival and moved to smaller venue DOM [http://www.dom.com.ru] (but on the same date). Musically the Concert was a big success and the organization went very smooth, but the whole tendency of decreasing audiences and lack of people's enthusiasm continued, making the future of the festival again very uncertain.
Meanwhile, the resque came from prog enthusiast from Yaroslavl' town, who offered to make local branch of the festival. New festival called "Yaroslavl' InProg" became a mix of musicians from Moscow and Yaroslavl' and happened, to local success, even twice in a year 2010.
"InProg on the Hills" has continued in 2011. A mix of Russian and Ukraine bands played there, including well-known [[Sunchild]].
== List of all festivals and performers ==
'''InProg on the Hills 2011''' (10 June-13 June) :[[Art-Nechto]] (Arkhangelsk-Moscow), [[Introspective F.M.]] (Yaroslavl'), [[Uphill Work]] (Moscow), [[Eternal Wanderers]] (Moscow), [[Cracked Rombix]] (Moscow), [[Sunchild]] (Kharkiv, Ukraine), [[Mystic Morrison Visions]] (Volzhskiy, Russia), [[Chikiss]] (St.Petersburg).
'''InProg on the Hills 2010''' (11 June-13 June) :[[Uphill Work]], [[Syncopated Silence]], [[Olga Dzusova]] & SS-20, [[Orgia Pravednikov]] (All - Moscow, Russia), [[Kusudama]] (Minsk, Belarus) - main progrock/metal/etc. set at 11 June. "Orgia" show was a big success. :[[Vespero]] (Astrakhan'), Klever (St.Petersburg), [[Cracked Rombix]] (Moscow), [[Mouches a l'Orange]] (Soligorsk, Belarus) - psychedelic set at 13 June. Due to dysfunctional stage/weather conditions it was moved to different stage and went late night and in-between reggae (!!!) set; weird mix indeed.
'''InProg 2009''' (24 October) :[[Beardfish (band)|Beardfish]] ([[Sweden]]), [[Vespero]] ([[Russia]]), [[The Worm Ouroboros (band)|The Worm Ouroboros]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y8XldC0DC1c "The Worm Ouroboros" 24.10.2009, InProg-2009, Moskva]</ref> ([[Belarus]]), Jazzator ([[Russia]]).
'''InProg on the Hills 2009''' (12 June-13 June) :[[Jazzator]], [[Vespero]], [[Kostarev Group]]. Most of the planned bands were cancelled.
'''Ecco Prog Fest 2008''' (29 November) :[[Flower Kings]] ([[Sweden]]), [[Apple Pie (band)|Apple Pie]] ([[Russia]]), [[Batisfera]] ([[Russia]]) and [[Kostarev Group]] ([[Russia]]).
'''InProg on the Hills 2008''' (12 June) :[[Rational Diet]] ([[Belarus]]), [[Disen Gage]] ([[Russia]]), [[Inner Drive]] ([[Russia]]), [[Batisfera]] ([[Russia]]), [[EXIT project]] ([[Russia]]), [[Olga Dzusova]] & SS-20 ([[Russia]]), [[Kaftan Smeha]] ([[Russia]]). :On 13 June, [[progressive rock]] bands [[Kostarev Group]] ([[Russia]]) and [[The Skys]] ([[Lithuania]]) also played.
'''InProg 2006''' (9 April and 23 April) :Day 1 - [[Vicheslav Gorskiy & Kvadro]], [[EXIT project]], [[Blind Vandal]], [[Olle Lukoye]], [[Kaftan Smeha]], a [[Jam session]] of different musicians led by [[Alexander Kostarev]], who was specially invited to lead the [[Jam session]]. :Day 2 - [[Little Tragedies (rock group)|Little Tragedies]], [[Azazello (band)|Azazello]], [[Extrovert (band)|Extrovert]], [[Nightingale (band)|Nightingale]] ([[Sweden]]).
*All performers from [[Russia]], except where noted.
'''InProg 2005''' (14–15 May) :Day 1 - [[Samla Mammas Manna]] ([[Sweden]]), [[Tanquam]], [[Invisible Front]], [[Andrey Suchilin|Andrey Suchilin and Do Major Neo]]. :Day 2 - [[Olive Mess]] ([[Latvia]]), [[Hidria Spacefolk]] ([[Finland]]), [[Alexander Kostarev|Kostarev Group]], [[Marimba Plus]], [[Disen Gage]].
*All performers from [[Russia]], except where noted.
'''InProg 2004''' (11 April) :[[Arsenal (Russian band)|Arsenal]], [[Alexander Kostarev|Kostarev Group]], [[Disen Gage|Disengage]], NYL, [[Metropolis (Russian band)|Metropolis]].
'''InProg 2003''' (15, 22 February) :Day 1 - [[Nova Art]], [[Orgiya Pravednikov]], [[Face-X]], [[Azazello (band)|Azazello]]. :Day 2 - NYL, [[Alexander Kostarev|Kostarev Group]], [[Azazello (band)|Azazello]].
* There was also a one-day InProg 2003 festival in [[Sankt Peterburg]] (16 February).
'''InProg 2001''' (11 November) :[[Azazello (band)|Azazello]], [[Face-X]], NYL, [[Nordream]], [[Elisium]].
